etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in John Hall (1529–1568/9), surgeon and author. From post-classical Latin repletivus serving to fill up the sentence, capable of filling or satisfying from classical Latin replēt-, past participial stem of replēre + -īvus

definitions: That fills, satiates, or supplies something in abundance; causing or providing repletion.
Fully present or existing everywhere, though in a non-physical manner. Used especially with reference to the ubiquity of God; compare "circumscriptive""definitive". Now chiefly historical.

notes.text: Chiefly used with reference to medieval Scholastic thought.
